citation.article-title: Leifsonia gen. nov., a genus for 2,4-diaminobutyric acid-containing actinomycetes to accommodate Corynebacterium aquaticum Leifson 1962 and Clavibacter xyli subsp. cynodontis Davis et al. 1984
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Leifsonia naganoensis sp. nov.
Leifsonia naganoensis (na.ga.no.en'sis N. L. adj. naganoensis referring to the Nagano Prefecture, Japan [the source of soil sample from which the type strain was isolated])
Cells are Gram-positive, obligatory aerobic, and nonspore forming rods (generally 0.3 to 0.5 by 1.8 to 3.0 μm in a 2-day culture).
Colonies on R agar are glossy, smooth, and entire.
White colonies of a 2-day-culture turn to pale brown in old culture at 30°C.
Weak growth at 37°C and not at 42°C.
Acid is produced from fructose, glycerol, D-xylose, maltose, mannose, L-rhamnose, glucose, galactose, mannitol, melibiose, salicin, sucrose, D-trehalose, and amygdalin, but not from inulin.
Lactate, pyruvate, fumarate, malate, and n-butyrate are assimilated, but formate, citrate, succinate, and propionate are not.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
The predominant menaquinones are MK-11 and MK-10.
The G+C content of DNA is 71 mol%.
The type strain of L. naganoensis is DB103 (JCM 10592).
The source of isolation is soil.
